pullRequest.body:
* Prove Helly's convexity theorem (including compact and set versions) and fix typos in `Analysis.Convex.Radon`
* Add alias `Set.sInter_mono` in the style of `Set.sUnion_mono`
* Mark  `encard_coe_eq_coe_finsetCard` with `simp` and `norm_cast`

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #14062

This PR is a natural continuation of  my recent PR #6598, introducing Radon's theorem.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Thank you very much! And sorry for such a delay. I learned a lot from your comments. In the end, I decided to keep your proof. I don't think I can improve it :)

I added you to the authors list in the heading. Hope you don't mind.
@vasnesterov can you address the earlier unresolved comments?
I added a comment about the theorem at the beginning, switched to indexed families instead sets and proved the infinite version.

It would be nice if we could get this PR moving again – to my (inexpert) eyes it looks like a really good contribution that would be great to get into mathlib.

I gather from discussion with Mitchell that the main unresolved issue is replacing uses of `Set.Finite` with `Finset`. @vasnesterov, is that something you'd be prepared to do in order to get this PR finished?

I would be happy to continue (was busy last two months). But I don't understand, why do we have `Set.Finite` in Mathlib if it should always be replaced with `Finset`? I thought that `Finset` is for "computational" things, which is not the case here.

I think the point is that in situations like this one – where you know from the start that a certain set is guaranteed to be finite, rather than finiteness being a possibility that may or may not arise – using `Finset` leads to shorter and more self-explanatory code without wasting time checking obvious side conditions. Relatedly, a lot of the API for sums, etc, expects a `Finset` or `Fintype` as domain, so using Finsets gives more seamless access to this API.

A good thing to remember is that `s : Finset ι` is more general than `Fintype ι`

I would just move this to the `Analysis.Convex.Radon` file, as that file only has the `convex_partition` declaration anyway, and the imports for the current file are not egregious.

This looks pretty good, but I haven't had an in-depth think about possible ways to improve the proof yet. I'll come back to that later. For now, here are a few comments.

I've left some comments below, but mainly I added them for your own benefit so you can see how I transformed the proof into what I am copying below. If you want, you can just copy this proof and resolve the conversations below after you have read and understand them. If you want me to explain any part of this proof I'm happy to. Note: it was *not* the case that your proof was bad. I'm only trying to show you alternative techniques that can make things a bit easier for you.
```lean
/-- **Helly's theorem on convex sets**: If `F` is a finite family of convex sets in a vector space
of finite dimension `d`, and any `d + 1` sets of `F` intersect, then all sets of `F` intersect. -/
theorem helly_theorem (F : Set (Set E)) {hF_fin : Set.Finite F}
    (h_card : (finrank 𝕜 E) + 1 ≤ ncard F) (h_convex : ∀ X ∈ F, Convex 𝕜 X)
    (h_inter : ∀ G : Set (Set E), (G ⊆ F) → (ncard G = (finrank 𝕜 E) + 1) →
    (⋂₀ G).Nonempty) : (⋂₀ F).Nonempty := by
  obtain ⟨n, hn⟩ : ∃ n : ℕ, ncard F = n := ⟨ncard F, rfl⟩ -- for induction on ncard F
  rw [hn] at h_card
  induction' n, h_card using Nat.le_induction with k h_card hk generalizing F
  exact h_inter F (Eq.subset rfl) hn
  /- construct a family of vectors indexed by `F` such that the vector corresponding to `X : F` is
  an arbitrary element of the intersection `⋂₀ F` which *does not lie in `X`*. -/
  let a : F → E := fun X : F ↦ Set.Nonempty.some (s := ⋂₀ (F \ {(X : Set E)})) <| by
    apply @hk _ (Finite.diff hF_fin {(X : Set E)})
    · exact fun Y hY ↦ h_convex Y (mem_of_mem_diff hY)
    · exact fun G hG_1 hG_2 ↦ h_inter G (Subset.trans hG_1 (diff_subset F {(X : Set E)})) hG_2
    · rw [ncard_diff_singleton_of_mem X.property hF_fin, Nat.sub_eq_of_eq_add hn]
  /- This family of vectors is not affine independent because the number of them exceeds the
  dimension of the space. -/
  have h2 : ¬AffineIndependent 𝕜 a := by
    have : Fintype ↑F := Finite.fintype hF_fin -- for instance inferring
    rw [←finrank_vectorSpan_le_iff_not_affineIndependent 𝕜 a (n := (k - 1))]
    · exact (Submodule.finrank_le (vectorSpan 𝕜 (Set.range a))).trans (Nat.le_pred_of_lt h_card)
    · rw [←Finite.card_toFinset hF_fin, ←ncard_eq_toFinset_card F hF_fin, hn,
        ←Nat.sub_add_comm (Nat.one_le_of_lt h_card)]
      rfl
  /- Use `Convex.radon_partition` to conclude there is a subset `I` of `F` and a point `p : E`
  which lies in the convex hull of either `a '' I` or `a '' Iᶜ`. We claim that `p ∈ ⋂₀ F`.
  (here `Iᶜ` is the complement within `F`, i.e., it is effectively `F \ I`.) -/
  obtain ⟨I, p, h4_I, h4_Ic⟩ := Convex.radon_partition h2
  refine ⟨p, fun X hX ↦ ?_⟩
  lift X to F using hX
  /- It suffices to show that for any set `X` in a subcollection `I` of `F`, that the convex hull
  of `a '' Iᶜ` is contained in `X`. -/
  suffices ∀ I : Set F, X ∈ I → (convexHull 𝕜) (a '' Iᶜ) ⊆ X by
    by_cases (X ∈ I)
    · exact this I h h4_Ic
    · apply this Iᶜ h; rwa [compl_compl]
  /- Given any subcollection `I` of `F` containing `X`, because `X` is convex, we need only show
  that `a Y ∈ X` for each `Y ∈ Iᶜ` -/
  intro I h
  rw [Convex.convexHull_subset_iff (h_convex _ X.prop)]
  rintro - ⟨Y, hY, rfl⟩
  /- Since `Y ∈ Iᶜ` and `X ∈ I`, we conclude that `X ≠ Y`, and hence by the definition of `a`:
  `a Y ∈ ⋂₀ F \ {Y} ⊆ X`  -/
  have : X ≠ Y := fun h' ↦ hY (h' ▸ h)
  exact (sInter_subset_of_mem <| mem_diff_singleton.mpr ⟨X.prop, Subtype.coe_injective.ne this⟩)
    (Set.Nonempty.some_mem _)
```

I would like to get this merged sooner rather than later. So if you have any questions let me know. Otherwise ping me (i.e., request my review) when you add the set version back in and I'll do a last review.

Hi, I saw this in the queue and decided to take a look. This is a great contribution.

I am sorry for potentially delaying this even further, but I am going to ask you to make a few changes that I think are low-cost and/or important. Most of them are very minor simplifications to the proofs.

Thank you!
Sorry for missing these earlier
A good thing to remember is that `s : Finset ι` is more general than `Fintype ι`

It would be nice to give a brief comment that this fails for infinite families by giving a counterexample (e.g., the rays `Set.Ici (n : ℝ)` for `n : ℕ`).

It seems like there should be a nice corollary here though: if the convex sets are also compact then it should hold for infinite families as well. I'm not sure whether it is worth adding that corollary, but perhaps.
Yes, I'm going to prove the infinite compact version too. Should I prove this counterexample in Lean, or just mention in the docs?
Mentioning it in the docs is fine, especially with a reference to the infinite compact version.

Could you prove a version of this that uses indexed collections? e.g., something like:
```lean
theorem helly_theorem' {ι : Type*} [Fintype ι] (f : ι → Set E)
    (h_card : (finrank 𝕜 E) + 1 ≤ ncard (range f)) (h_convex : ∀ i : ι, Convex 𝕜 (f i))
    (h_inter : ∀ g : Fin (finrank 𝕜 E + 1) → ι, (Function.Injective g) → (⋂ n, f (g n)).Nonempty) :
    (⋂ i, f i).Nonempty := sorry
```
maybe this also needs an `Function.Injective f` hypothesis, in which case you could state `h_card` as `(finrank 𝕜 E) + 1 ≤ Fintype.card ι`.

Lean 4 has a cool new syntax for filling in implicit arguments explicitly:
```suggestion
    rw [←finrank_vectorSpan_le_iff_not_affineIndependent 𝕜 a (n := (k - 1))]
```

This adheres to the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html), in case you haven't seen it yet.
```suggestion
    · rw [←Finite.card_toFinset hF_fin, ←ncard_eq_toFinset_card F hF_fin, hn,
        ←Nat.sub_add_comm (Nat.one_le_of_lt h_card)]
      rfl
```

Here and throughout the proof: we generally don't leave blank lines in proofs. The indentation should be enough to distinguish different subproofs. However, if you want to provide code comments that document the various steps of the proof, that is highly encouraged!
```suggestion
```

This should be on 3 separate lines instead of separated by `;`, and this is a non-terminal `simp`, so it should be squeezed using `simp?` and then you can click the "Try this: ..." suggestion it provides. See [this section](https://leanprover-community.github.io/extras/simp.html#non-terminal-simps) of the page about `simp` for information about non-terminal `simp` usage.

There's a nice short way to do this:
```suggestion
    rintro - ⟨Y, hY, rfl⟩
```

The `rw` isn't necessary, and then you can just make this:
```suggestion
  refine ⟨p, fun X hX ↦ ?_⟩ -- this is equivalent to what you had before
  lift X to F using hX -- this is extra
```
Note that `lift` allows us to go from viewing `X : Set E` with a proof of `X ∈ F`, to `X : F`. This is nice for the remainder of the proof since `a : F → E`. This means you can avoid doing things like `⟨X, hX⟩` and `⟨Y, hY⟩`.

Instead of `have h1 : ...`, and then `let a : F → E`, I think it makes more sense to just do:
```suggestion
  let a : F → E := fun X : F ↦ Set.Nonempty.some (s := ⋂₀ (F \ {(X : Set E)})) <| by
    -- proof of `h1` here
```
Note that you don't actually need `h1` later in the proof, and you can instead use `Set.Nonempty.some_mem _`.
This is a bit of a stylistic preference, but instead of `have h4 : ...`, I would use `suffices`, and then insert this short `by_cases` proof immediately afterwards.

with the `lift` suggested above, this can be golfed quite a bit, and to be honest, `mem_of_subset_of_mem` is kind of a superfluous lemma. You can just replace it with a proof of the subset fact, and then apply it to a proof of membership in the smaller set.

```suggestion
As a corollary, we prove Helly's theorem, which is a basic result in discrete geometry on the
intersection of convex sets. Let `X₁, ⋯, Xₙ` be a finite family of convex sets in `ℝᵈ` with
`n ≥ d + 1`. The theorem states that if any `d + 1` sets from this family intersect nontrivially, then the whole
family intersect nontrivially. For the infinite family of sets it is not true, as example of `Set.Ioo 0 (1 / n)` for
`n : ℕ` shows. But the statement is true, if we assume compactness of sets (see
```
Note: I didn't mean for you to *get rid of* the set version in favor of the indexed version. I think we should have both. (Although you should probably prove one from the other.)

```suggestion
theorem Convex.helly_theorem (F : ι → Set E) [Finite ι]
```

This allows the finiteness of `ι` to be inferred through typeclass inference. This change might necessitate a few minor changes in the rest of the code, but it is quite important in my opinion.

```suggestion
  · generalize hn : Nat.card ι = n
```
Thanks a lot! A was looking for this.


The hypothesis that `ι` is infinite is never used except to deduce that `ι` is nonempty. But if `ι` is empty, then the theorem is trivial. So the hypothesis that `ι` is infinite is not necessary. You may have to slightly rewrite the end of the proof in order to get rid of this hypothesis.

```suggestion

    (⋂ i : ι, F i).Nonempty := by
```

This was found by typing `#minimize_imports` at the end of the file.

```suggestion
theorem Convex.helly_theorem_set {F : Set (Set E)} (hF_fin : Set.Finite F)
```

`F` can be deduced from the type of `hF_fin`, so it should be the implicit one.

(A more idiomatic way of stating this pair of hypotheses is `(F : Finset (Set E))`. In fact, I would argue that many of the occurrences of `Set` in this file could be replaced by `Finset` and the theorems would become easier to use. One benefit of this approach is that you could replace every occurrence of `ncard` with the better-behaved `Finset.card`. However, this would require significant changes, so it's okay to leave it as is for now.)
I tried to use `Finset`, but it requires `DecidableEq ι` in the part of the proof where we reason about "all indexes but one".
It's on my to-do list to finish my review here, but I was also going to suggest `Finset` among other things. You can get around the need for `DecodableEq` by invoking `classical` in the proof.
Can you give me some kind of intuition here? When is `Finset` preferable to `Set.Finite`?

If you can package two hypotheses `F : Set β` and `hF_fin : Set.Finite F` into one hypothesis `F : Finset β`, that almost always makes the theorem easier to use.

I don't think that `Set.Finite` and `ncard` should be used at all in this file.


```suggestion
          rw [show ⋂ i ∈ J, F' i = ⋂ i ∈ Subtype.val '' J, F i by simp]
```

```suggestion
    (⋂₀ F).Nonempty := by
```



You don't need `n ≥ d + 1` at all, right?

I am not sure here. In the [classical form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helly%27s_theorem), Helly's theorem requires `n ≥ d + 1` and the intersection of any (exactly) `d + 1` sets to be nonempty, while I drop the `n ≥ d + 1` assumption but assume that the intersection of any collection of *no more* than `d + 1` intersects nontrivially. The classical form follows from the proved one trivially, but maybe we should have the former as `helly_theorem` and the latter as its version.
Sure, I guess that's minutiae
I decided to add the classical variation only for the main theorem. Otherwise, we would have 8 Helly's theorems: (families/sets) × (finite/compact) × (classical form/the other form).

Is that bad? After all that's what API is for.

See eg `Algebra.Order.Rearrangement` for an example of many copies of one statement

It's usually nicer to use bespoke lemmas when casing on `a < b` or `b ≤ a`
```suggestion
  obtain h_card | h_card := lt_or_le (Fintype.card ι) (finrank 𝕜 E + 1)
  · exact helly_theorem_corner (le_of_lt h_card) h_inter
  · generalize hn : Fintype.card ι = n
    rw [hn] at h_card
```

When one case is clearly the main one, no need to indent it
```suggestion
  generalize hn : Fintype.card ι = n
  rw [not_lt, hn] at h_card
  induction' n, h_card using Nat.le_induction with k h_card hk generalizing ι
  · exact helly_theorem_corner (le_of_eq hn) h_inter
  /- Construct a family of vectors indexed by `ι` such that the vector corresponding to `i : ι`
  is an arbitrary element of the intersection of all `F j` except `F i`. -/
  let a (i : ι) : E := Set.Nonempty.some (s := ⋂₀ (F '' (Finset.univ.erase i))) <| by
    let ι' :=  Finset.univ.erase i
    let F' : ι' → Set E := fun i ↦ F i
    rw [show ⋂₀ (F '' ι') = ⋂ i, F' i by simp [Set.iInter_subtype]]
    apply hk (F := F')
    · exact fun i ↦ h_convex ↑i
    · intro J hJ_card
      rw [show ⋂ i ∈ J, F' i = ⋂ i ∈ Finset.image Subtype.val J, F i by
        simp [Set.iInter_subtype]]
      exact h_inter _ (le_trans Finset.card_image_le hJ_card)
    · simp [ι']; omega

  /- This family of vectors is not affine independent because the number of them exceeds the
  dimension of the space. -/
  have h_ind : ¬AffineIndependent 𝕜 a := by
    rw [← finrank_vectorSpan_le_iff_not_affineIndependent 𝕜 a (n := (k - 1))]
    · exact (Submodule.finrank_le (vectorSpan 𝕜 (Set.range a))).trans (Nat.le_pred_of_lt h_card)
    · omega
  /- Use `Convex.radon_partition` to conclude there is a subset `I` of `ι` and a point `p : E`
  which lies in the convex hull of either `a '' I` or `a '' Iᶜ`. We claim that `p ∈ ⋂₀ F`. -/
  obtain ⟨I, p, h4_I, h4_Ic⟩ := Convex.radon_partition h_ind
  use p
  apply Set.mem_iInter_of_mem
  intro i
  /- It suffices to show that for any set `F i` in a subcollection `I` of `ι`, that the convex
  hull of `a '' Iᶜ` is contained in `F i`. -/
  suffices ∀ I : Set ι, i ∈ I → (convexHull 𝕜) (a '' Iᶜ) ⊆ F i by
    by_cases h : i ∈ I
    · exact this I h h4_Ic
    · apply this Iᶜ h; rwa [compl_compl]
  /- Given any subcollection `I` of `ι` containing `i`, because `F i` is convex, we need only
  show that `a j ∈ F i` for each `j ∈ Iᶜ`. -/
  intro I hi
  rw [Convex.convexHull_subset_iff (h_convex i)]
  rintro - ⟨j, hj, rfl⟩
  /- Since `j ∈ Iᶜ` and `i ∈ I`, we conclude that `i ≠ j`, and hence by the definition of `a`:
  `a j ∈ ⋂ F '' (Set.univ \ {j}) ⊆ F i`. -/
  apply Set.mem_of_subset_of_mem (s₁ := ⋂₀ (F '' (Finset.univ.erase j)))
  · apply sInter_subset_of_mem
    use i
    simp only [coe_erase, coe_univ, mem_diff, Set.mem_univ, mem_singleton_iff, true_and,
      and_true]
    exact fun h' ↦ hj (h' ▸ hi)
  · apply Set.Nonempty.some_mem
```

Can you avoid making the only description of an important "It's like this other result except for that thing that changes"? It makes it really annoying when you hover over it and try to understand what it says.
```suggestion
/-- **Helly's theorem** for finite sets of convex sets.

If `F` is a finite set of convex sets in a vector space of finite dimension `d`,
and any `d + 1` sets of `F` intersect, then all sets of `F` intersect. -/
```

Then here you can do
```suggestion
/-- **Helly's theorem** for finite families of convex sets.

If `F` is a finite family of convex sets in a vector space of finite dimension `d`,
and any `d + 1` sets of `F` intersect, then all sets of `F` intersect. -/
```

Technically, this does not ask the family to be infinite, so I would rather call it
```suggestion
theorem helly_theorem_family_compact [TopologicalSpace E] [T2Space E] (F : ι → Set E)
```
and note that you are missing `helly_theorem_set_compact`, the set version

```suggestion
/-- **Helly's theorem** for families of compact convex sets.

If `F` is a family of compact convex sets in a vector space of finite dimension `d`,
and any `d + 1` sets of `F` intersect, then all sets of `F` intersect. -/
```

```suggestion
    (h_card : finrank 𝕜 E + 1 ≤ PartENat.card ι)
```
maybe?

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.FiniteDimensional

```

```suggestion
/-- **Radon's theorem on convex sets**.

Any family `f` of affine dependent vectors contains a set `I` with the property that convex hulls of
`I` and `Iᶜ` intersect nontrivially. -/
```
to follow the "short docstring-long docstring" convention
Same here and below

```suggestion
    (h_convex : ∀ i, Convex 𝕜 (F i))
```

```suggestion
**Helly's theorem** for finite families of convex sets of the same size.
```
seems more descriptive (and elsewhere)
I think this would be misleading, because it's not about convex sets of the same size, but about finsets of these sets with a fixed size. I'm not sure how to make it more descriptive anyway.

@grunweg, seems like the old obtain would be better here... For now, maybe this is better indentation?

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨J, _, hJ_ss, hJ_card⟩ := exists_superset_subset_encard_eq hI_ss (hkt := h_card)
    (by simpa only [encard_coe_eq_coe_finsetCard, ← ENat.coe_one, ← ENat.coe_add, Nat.cast_le])
```

Lemmas around this are a mess, so I opened #14062.
This should also be `norm_cast`

```suggestion
  apply mem_of_subset_of_mem (s₁ := ⋂₀ F '' Finset.univ.erase j)
```
or even
```suggestion
  apply mem_of_subset_of_mem (s₁ := ⋂₀ F '' {j}ᶜ)
```

When one goal is clearly the main one/much longer than the rest, we tend to unindent it
```suggestion
  apply Convex.helly_theorem' (F := fun x : F ↦ x.val) (𝕜 := 𝕜)
  · exact fun X ↦ h_convex X (by simp)
  intro G _
  let G' : Finset (Set E) := Finset.image Subtype.val G
  rw [show ⋂ i ∈ G, ↑i = ⋂₀ (G' : Set (Set E)) by simp [G']]
  apply h_inter G'
  · rw [Finset.image_subset_iff]
    simp
  · apply le_trans Finset.card_image_le
    assumption
```

Why do you need to explicit so many arguments? I would expect one of these works:
```suggestion
  refine Convex.helly_theorem' (F := fun x : F ↦ x.val) (fun X ↦ h_convex X (by simp)) ?_
```
or
```suggestion
  refine Convex.helly_theorem' (fun x : F ↦ h_convex x.1 x.2) ?_
```

```suggestion
theorem helly_theorem' {F : ι → Set E} {s : Finset ι}
    (h_convex : ∀ i ∈ s, Convex 𝕜 (F i))
    (h_inter : ∀ I ⊆ s, I.card ≤ finrank 𝕜 E + 1 → (⋂ i ∈ I, F i).Nonempty) :
    (⋂ i ∈ s, F i).Nonempty := by
```
will make the induction much easier...

... namely
```suggestion
  induction' s using Finset.induction
```
and more simplifications below
Here it is more convenient to use induction on the size of the set rather than its elements.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/Convex): Helly's convexity theorem

nodes.body:
I would just move this to the `Analysis.Convex.Radon` file, as that file only has the `convex_partition` declaration anyway, and the imports for the current file are not egregious.

This looks pretty good, but I haven't had an in-depth think about possible ways to improve the proof yet. I'll come back to that later. For now, here are a few comments.

I've left some comments below, but mainly I added them for your own benefit so you can see how I transformed the proof into what I am copying below. If you want, you can just copy this proof and resolve the conversations below after you have read and understand them. If you want me to explain any part of this proof I'm happy to. Note: it was *not* the case that your proof was bad. I'm only trying to show you alternative techniques that can make things a bit easier for you.
```lean
/-- **Helly's theorem on convex sets**: If `F` is a finite family of convex sets in a vector space
of finite dimension `d`, and any `d + 1` sets of `F` intersect, then all sets of `F` intersect. -/
theorem helly_theorem (F : Set (Set E)) {hF_fin : Set.Finite F}
    (h_card : (finrank 𝕜 E) + 1 ≤ ncard F) (h_convex : ∀ X ∈ F, Convex 𝕜 X)
    (h_inter : ∀ G : Set (Set E), (G ⊆ F) → (ncard G = (finrank 𝕜 E) + 1) →
    (⋂₀ G).Nonempty) : (⋂₀ F).Nonempty := by
  obtain ⟨n, hn⟩ : ∃ n : ℕ, ncard F = n := ⟨ncard F, rfl⟩ -- for induction on ncard F
  rw [hn] at h_card
  induction' n, h_card using Nat.le_induction with k h_card hk generalizing F
  exact h_inter F (Eq.subset rfl) hn
  /- construct a family of vectors indexed by `F` such that the vector corresponding to `X : F` is
  an arbitrary element of the intersection `⋂₀ F` which *does not lie in `X`*. -/
  let a : F → E := fun X : F ↦ Set.Nonempty.some (s := ⋂₀ (F \ {(X : Set E)})) <| by
    apply @hk _ (Finite.diff hF_fin {(X : Set E)})
    · exact fun Y hY ↦ h_convex Y (mem_of_mem_diff hY)
    · exact fun G hG_1 hG_2 ↦ h_inter G (Subset.trans hG_1 (diff_subset F {(X : Set E)})) hG_2
    · rw [ncard_diff_singleton_of_mem X.property hF_fin, Nat.sub_eq_of_eq_add hn]
  /- This family of vectors is not affine independent because the number of them exceeds the
  dimension of the space. -/
  have h2 : ¬AffineIndependent 𝕜 a := by
    have : Fintype ↑F := Finite.fintype hF_fin -- for instance inferring
    rw [←finrank_vectorSpan_le_iff_not_affineIndependent 𝕜 a (n := (k - 1))]
    · exact (Submodule.finrank_le (vectorSpan 𝕜 (Set.range a))).trans (Nat.le_pred_of_lt h_card)
    · rw [←Finite.card_toFinset hF_fin, ←ncard_eq_toFinset_card F hF_fin, hn,
        ←Nat.sub_add_comm (Nat.one_le_of_lt h_card)]
      rfl
  /- Use `Convex.radon_partition` to conclude there is a subset `I` of `F` and a point `p : E`
  which lies in the convex hull of either `a '' I` or `a '' Iᶜ`. We claim that `p ∈ ⋂₀ F`.
  (here `Iᶜ` is the complement within `F`, i.e., it is effectively `F \ I`.) -/
  obtain ⟨I, p, h4_I, h4_Ic⟩ := Convex.radon_partition h2
  refine ⟨p, fun X hX ↦ ?_⟩
  lift X to F using hX
  /- It suffices to show that for any set `X` in a subcollection `I` of `F`, that the convex hull
  of `a '' Iᶜ` is contained in `X`. -/
  suffices ∀ I : Set F, X ∈ I → (convexHull 𝕜) (a '' Iᶜ) ⊆ X by
    by_cases (X ∈ I)
    · exact this I h h4_Ic
    · apply this Iᶜ h; rwa [compl_compl]
  /- Given any subcollection `I` of `F` containing `X`, because `X` is convex, we need only show
  that `a Y ∈ X` for each `Y ∈ Iᶜ` -/
  intro I h
  rw [Convex.convexHull_subset_iff (h_convex _ X.prop)]
  rintro - ⟨Y, hY, rfl⟩
  /- Since `Y ∈ Iᶜ` and `X ∈ I`, we conclude that `X ≠ Y`, and hence by the definition of `a`:
  `a Y ∈ ⋂₀ F \ {Y} ⊆ X`  -/
  have : X ≠ Y := fun h' ↦ hY (h' ▸ h)
  exact (sInter_subset_of_mem <| mem_diff_singleton.mpr ⟨X.prop, Subtype.coe_injective.ne this⟩)
    (Set.Nonempty.some_mem _)
```

Thank you very much! And sorry for such a delay. I learned a lot from your comments. In the end, I decided to keep your proof. I don't think I can improve it :)

I added you to the authors list in the heading. Hope you don't mind.
@vasnesterov can you address the earlier unresolved comments?
I added a comment about the theorem at the beginning, switched to indexed families instead sets and proved the infinite version.

I would like to get this merged sooner rather than later. So if you have any questions let me know. Otherwise ping me (i.e., request my review) when you add the set version back in and I'll do a last review.

Hi, I saw this in the queue and decided to take a look. This is a great contribution.

I am sorry for potentially delaying this even further, but I am going to ask you to make a few changes that I think are low-cost and/or important. Most of them are very minor simplifications to the proofs.

Thank you!
Sorry for missing these earlier

It would be nice if we could get this PR moving again – to my (inexpert) eyes it looks like a really good contribution that would be great to get into mathlib.

I gather from discussion with Mitchell that the main unresolved issue is replacing uses of `Set.Finite` with `Finset`. @vasnesterov, is that something you'd be prepared to do in order to get this PR finished?

I would be happy to continue (was busy last two months). But I don't understand, why do we have `Set.Finite` in Mathlib if it should always be replaced with `Finset`? I thought that `Finset` is for "computational" things, which is not the case here.

I think the point is that in situations like this one – where you know from the start that a certain set is guaranteed to be finite, rather than finiteness being a possibility that may or may not arise – using `Finset` leads to shorter and more self-explanatory code without wasting time checking obvious side conditions. Relatedly, a lot of the API for sums, etc, expects a `Finset` or `Fintype` as domain, so using Finsets gives more seamless access to this API.
